sentences.text: General elections were held in Palau on 5 November 2024 to elect a President of Palau|President and the Palau National Congress|National Congress. Incumbent President Surangel Whipps Jr. faced former president Tommy Remengesau Jr. in the election, and was reelected in a landslide. This was the first presidential election where Remengesau lost.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-08-06 |title=Primary Election Decision Pending as Filing Deadline Approaches in Palau |url=https://islandtimes.org/primary-election-decision-pending-as-filing-deadline-approaches-in-palau/ |access-date=2024-09-07 |website=Island Times |language=en-US}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-08-26 |title=Whipps v Remengesau: Brothers-in-law to run against each other in 2024 Palau elections |url=https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/526208/whipps-v-remengesau-brothers-in-law-to-run-against-each-other-in-2024-palau-elections |access-date=2024-09-07 |website=RNZ |language=en-nz}}</ref>

sentences.text: The president was elected using the two-round system.

references.text: <ref>[http://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/2250/ Palau] IFES</ref>

sentences.text: The 15 members of the Senate of Palau|Senate were elected from a single nationwide constituency by Plurality-at-large voting|block voting, with each voter having 15 votes to cast. The 16 members of the House of Delegates of Palau|House of Delegates were elected in single-member constituencies based on the States of Palau|states using first-past-the-post voting.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Palau (House of Delegates), Electoral system|url=http://archive.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/2243_B.htm|website=Inter-Parliamentary Union}}</ref>

sentences.text: Campaigning was marred by diplomatic and economic issues. Tommy Remengesau Jr criticized growing security relations with the United States under Whipps' presidency, which the latter has supported as a "deterrent". Remengesau also pledged to revoke a 15% tax on goods introduced by Whipps.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-11-05 |title=Palau polls open as pro-US president faces election test |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20241105-palau-polls-open-as-pro-us-president-faces-election-test |access-date=2024-11-05 |website=France 24 |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Preliminary results appeared to show Surangel Whipps Jr. leading in the presidential race, while Raynold Oilouch was leading as vice president.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-11-06 |title=Unofficial election results coming in for Guam, Palau, CNMI |url=https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/532980/unofficial-election-results-coming-in-for-guam-palau-cnmi |access-date=2024-11-06 |website=RNZ |language=en}}</ref>

<ref name="taiwan"/> Whipps formally claimed victory on 11 November, while Remengesau conceded defeat earlier.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2024-11-11 |title=Pro-US incumbent claims victory in Palau presidential vote |url=https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20241111-pro-us-incumbent-claims-victory-in-palau-presidential-vote |access-date=2024-11-11 |website=France 24 |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Taiwanese president Lai Ching-te sent congratulations to Whipps and his vice president, Raynold Oilouch, upon their reelection and election respectively.

references.text: <ref name="taiwan">{{Cite web |date=2024-11-07 |title=Taiwan congratulates Palau President Whipps on reelection |url=https://focustaiwan.tw/politics/202411070028 |access-date=2024-11-07 |website=Focus Taiwan |language=en}}</ref>
